newsitem.title: USA: Philip Morris net up as tobacco, food businesses thrive.
newsitem.headline: Philip Morris net up as tobacco, food businesses thrive.

text.p: Philip Morris Cos Inc., the maker of Marlboro cigarettes and Miller beer, Wednesday reported robust fourth-quarter profits and said it set several records in 1996 as its worldwide tobacco and food businesses thrived.

Profits rose about 16 percent to $1.47 million in the quarter ended Dec. 31 from $1.27 million in the year-ago period. Earnings per share rose to $1.81 from $1.53, beating analysts' estimates of $1.80.
Revenues rose to $16.7 billion from $15.6 billion.
"We are beginning 1997 in great shape, and while the strength of the dollar is a factor that we have to contend with, our prospects remain robust," Chairman Geoffrey Bible said in a statement.
The New York-based company's other cigarette brands include Merit and Virginia Slims. The company's food brands include Kraft and Oscar Mayer and products such as Kool-Aid and Jell-O.

Full-year profits jumped 15 percent to $6.3 billion, or $7.68 a share, from $5.5 billion, or $6.48 a share, in 1995. Revenues rose to $68.94 billion from $63.77 billion, excluding North American food businesses divested since the beginning of 1995.

Philip Morris U.S.A., the company's U.S. tobacco business, said its earnings rose 12.5 percent to $4.2 billion in 1996. Improvements were driven by higher volume and a shift in sales to more profitable premium brands and pricing, it said.

In the United States, Philip Morris shipped a record 230.8 billion cigarettes in 1996. Marlboro, the company's flagship brand, also set records for volume and shipment share, while capturing 33.3 percent of the retail market, an all-time high.

Philip Morris International, its international tobacco operations, saw operating income rise 18.1 percent in 1996 to $4.1 billion from 1995. The company sold a record volume of 660 billion cigarettes, up 11.3 percent from 1995.
Worldwide volume sales for Marlboro, the world's best-selling cigarette, grew by 8.7 percent to 458 billion cigarettes, a record.
North American food posted record volume growth of 4.5 percent, and income rose 8.5 percent to $2.6 billion, Philip Morris said.
Worldwide food continued its solid growth, with operating income rising 8 percent to $3.9 billion due to volume gains, improved margins, continued cost reductions and acquisitions.
Overall volume sales rose partly due to strong coffee sales and the acquisition of Lacta, Brazil's leading chocolate company.

Miller Brewing's income fell 1.3 percent on lower volume. Miller Lite shipments and retail sales improved, and the business launched new initiatives to reinvigorate its core brands, Philip Morris said.
Philip Morris' stock rose $1 to $115.375 on the New York Stock Exchange in early afternoon trading.
